text: [Music]
hi everyone i'm kate warden and i'm so excited to be here today at go topia europe 2020 to talk about people first
leadership and the first thing i like to do is just walk through why i'm here
and so i'll go through three different reasons for why i'm here the first one actually is my mom um she we were
talking about when i first took on the role of a manager and how surprised she was that i had taken this
career path because she didn't feel like management was the right fit for my personality
and getting a little bit more deeper into it and talking to her um it sounded like she had a lot of bad bosses in the
past and so you know i took this as a compliment that she was surprised that i would take this career path knowing you
know those types of bosses that she had had and what i found in doing some research is that this isn't
uncommon so this perception of you know managers of leaders especially in technology um that she had
wasn't she wasn't alone in thinking that and so you know as the saying goes people don't leave jobs they leave
managers and according to a 2017 gallup engagement study
um 50 of respondents had left a job to get away from their manager at some point in
their career and this was actually a really really global study so they looked at 27
million different employees on 2.5 million different teams in almost 200 different countries so as
i said this is a global issue you know people are leaving jobs because of bad bosses and bad managers
and the second reason why i'm here is that i know that engineers are picky when choosing where to work
looking at our industry specifically according to the national center for education statistics data
they estimate that the people going into computer science related um degrees and graduating and you know
this year in 2020 is going to be about 70 000 people however according to the bureau of labor
statistics employment projections data there's going to be about 700 000
open software development roles um by the end of this year and growing
um so that's you know ten times the amount of open roles versus qualified candidates um and so as organizations and as
leaders i know that we are really gonna have um competition as people are choosing where they wanna work
as organizations we have to figure out you know how do we stand out and be these teams that people really want to come work for
um but also figure out how to retain people um and make sure that we're keeping them happy and energized and excited about working
on our development teams especially knowing that retention rates are at an all-time low
according to another gallup study they say about one in three people will leave their job for whatever reason
um and software development especially you know people are typically looking for
new roles about every two to two and a half years whether it's moving to a new team within the same organization hopefully or just entirely
leaving that organization for a new one and i've found that you know we can't afford to ignore this it's a really
expensive issue so 11 billion dollars is lost annually due to employee turnover
and they say that 75 of these causes are actually preventable which you know in my opinion by
really great leaders and the third reason why i'm here is that i've noticed um in doing research
that a lot of engineers are engineering managers are not receiving formal training when they become
an engineering manager for the first time um and i think you know this is this is quite ridiculous because it is
totally a career change you know you're going from computer science to to people science and leading humans um
and i know when you know a lot of other roles we're not expecting people to just jump into um all of these new skill sets just
expecting them to know exactly what to do but we provide them training and so seeing that less than half of those
folks who are entering the engineering management positions aren't receiving training is really discouraging and
something that i want to work on fixing so you know that's 60 percent um of us
left to figure out on their own um and like i said this is a true career change when you go from
being a developer or you know project manager to suddenly leading people
and so to recap those three reasons why i'm here you know number one we know that people are leaving bad managers
we know that employees and engineers specifically have many options when choosing where to work
and we know that a majority of these new leaders are feeling unprepared when they start in their role as an engineering
manager and so quick agenda here um you know we've gone through why are we talking
about this and why is this topic important i'm going gonna cover what is developer first leadership what is this people
first leadership concept um and what are some techniques that you can apply to your teams starting tomorrow
now i like to lead in to talk about you know why that first bullet you know why do bosses get a bad rap
and i think i think a lot of things naturally stem from you know the media that we're exposed to
if we don't have that formal training we're just gonna see and you know emulate what we see in the media so the bill lumbergs
of the world you know they're task givers they're micro managers they're intimidating um or they're just like relentlessly
cruel and cold um so we're emulating these bosses that we see when we don't have formal training
there's also a lot of admirable tech companies taking strong stances by seeing what happens when they completely
flatten their organizations um so you know zappos removed all managers at um a couple years back i think another
reason why is that you know sometimes we're promoting our best engineers into management positions who
really shouldn't or don't want to be people leaders um as i mentioned before we're going from computer science to people science
and i am a strong believer that you can apply technical skills to many different industries and jobs but it's really really hard to
apply those same technical skills directly to leadership because you know
the skills that made you an awesome lead engineer you know senior engineer will not necessarily make you an awesome
leader of people just right off the bat without some thought and some training i also
love this quote by the former vp of people operations at google um they did a study which i'll recap later
too called project oxygen um in which they looked at those great leaders um and some organizations without
managers um and saw what those teams with great leaders um what they looked like and what those
managers looked like and so they found that you know we always believed that to be a great manager you have to be as deep
or deeper technical expert than the people who work for you and it turns out based on their research so
this is absolutely the least important thing and so we're going to walk through some of these principles later on here too
another thing i like to call out you know on the soapbox is that let's try to make sure that there's multiple paths for people
at our organizations to um continue being compensated more without necessarily getting promoted into people
management positions so you know can you get to that type of level and that type of compensation at a lead or a principal or
distinguished or staff engineer like what do those career paths look like at your organization
and how can you make sure there's still challenging roles for people to work towards that don't necessarily have
to be people management all right so we can just give up um and also get rid of managers like some
companies are doing um i promised i'd reference this project oxygen study so
like i said google um also review removed some managers for some from some of their organizations to do a
study on what happened to the teams and what they found was that without managers
people are left searching for basic answers to questions and needs as well as guidance in important areas
such as career advice so to me i kind of think of that as like maslow's hierarchy of needs
you know just those things that you need to be successful those foundational things you need when
entering work and you know entering the workforce and just being a member of the team um that really foundational stuff to you
know be successful on a team and so that's great for myself and for other people in the role you know
managers are here to stay they're really valuable for many reasons um and i found that we do have to think
differently about leadership um so that we're not being those you know bad leaders that are making people
want to leave their organization let's just think differently about technical leadership and those are the
three reasons why i'm here and why this topic is especially important to me so we know that people are leaving bad
managers we know that engineers have a lot of options when choosing where to work and we know the majority of leaders
are feeling unprepared when they become an engineering manager for the first time and so to solve these problems you know
i think we need to develop awesome leaders foster irresistible cultures and also equip those new leaders with
the tools framework and confidence to be great leaders and i think just this just makes it so
important that we start with our managers um and i'm going to use the term manager and leader interchangeably
here so i like to walk through why i do that and why i think it's important that we recognize that
you know not all managers are leaders and why it's important to build essential skill sets in both areas
so all of these terms now supervisor manager leader they're all just trying to influence others to get stuff done
um but like i said i think they do have a lot of different skill sets and so obviously as a manager you have
to accomplish and lead some of these tasks like aligning people to work on you know the most important thing uh
monitoring budget and minimizing risks planning and prioritizing um and acting as that
interface between your team and the outside but then when it comes to leadership some of these actual skill sets we're
gonna be talking about today you know it's building strong teams it's providing feedback you're motivating
inspiring creating culture and unleashing potential so i just like to acknowledge and recognize that
when we talk about management and leadership they are very different things but both important to the role
all right so now getting back to the second topic here you know what is developer first leadership um it's actually a quite
simple but big mindset shift in the way that you think about leadership
so to me it's just that you know i work for my team and not the other way around and so i want to go through tactical
ways that you can practice some of these principles in your daily lives as an engineering manager or as a
leader tech lead on the team um that you can just start tomorrow
and so all these are going to kind of align to these three different categories so purpose people and process you know
purpose being what is your team trying to accomplish why does their work matter people you
know are the people the member of your teams motivated excited and growing professionally
and are the right people aligned to the right work based on their strengths and interests and then lastly processes
you know are expectations clear do people know how to work together productively
so we're gonna go through several different ways to practice developer first leadership starting
tomorrow the first one is to remove blockers that prevent people from making progress towards
professional and personal goals i really think that one of the most important roles is to enable developers
to be as productive as possible so in one on ones you know i'm asking people what they need
um and by the end of the day i have a big list of things that i can help them with and not the other way around
so whether it's gathering information from other teams finding them new opportunities to grow
in a particular skill set or business domain um influencing other teams to work on something that's blocking us
or helping them navigate a hard conversation um and so this can be as simple as
changing the way that you're phrasing your questions and one-on-ones so what can i help you with instead of
do you have an update on this this could also mean doing the unglamorous work as a leader
um you know as a leader if you're a peer on the team for if you're an engineer you know you're used to talking about
other things that are going wrong um and you know as a leader now you're accountable for taking action and taking
responsibility you know leading the team through fixing those problems and sometimes that means
doing some of the unglamorous work um one thing i'd like to talk about when i talk about removing blockers is to make
sure that you have a really solid onboarding program um employee onboarding is gonna make up you
know their first impression of your company and your team and so it's really the ideal place to set
standards because most people just want to start coding as soon as possible so i like to go through this checklist
um you know are you discussing the roles and responsibilities of both the new hire and yourself as the manager
you're discussing the team ways of working so you know we have to be online from this time to this time to support
our customers or our consumers or our providers whoever that is what are the expectations of the team
and when do they prefer to work how do they prefer to work hopefully you're providing an overview of the team
and the project and where it sits within the organization so i'm personally at a pretty large organization so i find myself
constantly trying to connect the dots so getting that out of the way right away you know drag on a whiteboard
you know here's our application here's the apps that we consume um that we send data to
here's all about our customers our users um here the key partners that you'll be working with
i think that's really important to get done off the bat then also matching the new hair with a
peer buddy and a mentor and these are very different roles so the mentor is that technical mentor who
the person can go to um you know regardless of you know what the topic is from a technical standpoint
so if they're working through a really complex issue or you know want that first person to review their pr
um that's the person they're going to go to and feel really comfortable to do so and then the peer buddy is just that person they can ask any type of question
to whether it's organizational you know um they witnessed a conversation that they just want to talk through and get
more information ask questions um that's the peer buddy role obviously in addition to you know the manager
yourself helping them through some of that stuff that peer buddies is just that unbiased person they can go to any time
then making sure you're helping the new hire build a social network so you're providing them with a list of
recommended people to meet with like i said before who are those key partners those developers they're going to be interfacing with
on other teams who are the sponsors and the leaders of our product that are going to care about the
you know the success of it so giving them a list of people to meet with right off the bat is going to be important
and then lastly i like to ask the new hire what they prefer for a welcome celebration so i found that not everyone wants you
know that happy hour so now maybe it's a virtual happy hour maybe they don't want that you know maybe they just want um
maybe if you're in the office you know donuts or you know something brought in a little bit um less formal maybe it's a
team lunch or maybe it's just a quick call for them to introduce themselves and for the team also to introduce
themselves so ask them what they prefer for that welcome celebration
now we have to make sure that also um our technical onboarding is ready for the new hire you have
access requests completed hopefully you have a laptop you know you're set you're helping them set up their development environment and
hopefully it's all documented along the way as well um you're providing visuals and diagrams of the architecture and the application
where it sits within the ecosystem of um you know the technology across your organization
the releases can be really intimidating the first time someone goes through it so making sure that this is really well
documented you know who and how do we communicate changes how do you go through that release process for the
first time and then of course just walking through you know other miscellaneous developer tools they'll have to use on a
day-to-day basis maybe they haven't used some of the tools that you have set up at your organization before
and so walking them through that is is really important within the first week
when we talk about blockers i also like to talk about blockers in disguise and here's where that really strong
interpersonal communication i think is vital as a technical leader um because blockers can disguise
themselves as dynamics amongst the team and so you have to be the one to you know bring that up if you see something
might be wrong um and this does require you to be really present so you know whether you're in the office
you're sitting with the team you're sitting you know in stand-ups and retros and demos absolutely
or you know virtual hopefully you're participating in you know slack channels or wherever the team is communicating so that you can watch out for some of these
blockers in disguise number two is to empower your team
i love this one um we have to make sure that we're ensuring that decisions are made at the level where the best information
is available and this is way easier said than done especially at a large company
there's a study from 1989 and i think it's absolutely still very applicable it's called the iceberg of ignorance and
it goes to show that you know very little um percent of those problems that are
causing so much trouble and those costly problems that are causing headaches on a day-to-day basis
are actually known by leaders um so four percent of problems are known by top level managers and then obviously you
know once you get down um to that bottom layer like a hundred percent of the problems are known by the frontline employees
you know so our development teams are working on them day in and day out and so i'd like to talk about how do we
melt you know metaphorically melt this iceberg um i think it's all about being humble
um you know we're seeking to understand pain points you're constantly asking how you can help someone
do their job better or you know make it more enjoyable for them you're doing anonymous post surveys
you're keeping your office door open you know metaphorically if you don't have an office just you're being a really approachable person and leader
like i said before you're sitting with the team you're asking them how they can do their jobs better um and hopefully you're doing something
like stay interviews so i'm sure most people are familiar with the concept of exit interviews
um in which you know maybe an hr partner would meet with the person as they've already decided to leave your
company just to learn about hey you know what went wrong what could we do better but let's have those conversations
before someone decides to leave our teams or our organizations and so i don't do them formally
but i think it's just important questions to ask in your one-on-ones to figure out you know if you had to leave tomorrow
what would be the main reason and how do we fix that while you're still here
when looking at making decisions you know make sure as a leader you're thinking about who should participate in making this decision who's gonna have to carry it
out and then who's gonna be impacted by the results of this decision i think this is just key things to think
about to be a lot more empowering leader and to make sure you're bringing the right people along
and i love this quote by steve jobs you know it doesn't make sense to hire smart people and tell them what to do we hire smart
people so that they can tell us what to do um you know i think this is especially relevant in technology when there's new
versions and frameworks and technology coming out all the time there's no way that a technical manager can keep up to date
and really you know lead their team through building technology like we just have to really rely on engineers to stay up to date and to make
these decisions for the teams another tip when it comes to empowering the team and
i give this one especially to those leaders who were you know peers on the team before so maybe they were coming from that lead
or senior engineer role and now they're managing the team um try to wait for conversations to play out before
offering up your opinion um people are going to look to you right away if you are always that person
offering it up um and you're going to become actually really harmful crutch for the team
not allowing them to feel empowered to make decisions without you um and i think this is really really
important to make sure that you're um when possible you know keeping quiet listen to them coming up with solutions
um and then you know what asked offer your your opinion via asking questions
i love this book called multipliers by liz wiseman it's um about two different types of leaders the
multiplier is like multiplying the genius around them because they aren't always the one to offer up their opinion
and then you know diminishers are diminishing the brilliance around them because they're always the one you know to to answer questions and
offer up ideas so here's a really great quote from that book multipliers get more from their people
because they're leaders who look beyond their own genius and focus their energy on extracting that
and extending the genius of others instead um you know i think once you are a leader of people it's really not about
you anymore it's about enabling others and helping them to grow professionally
another theme of empowerment you know knowledge should be spread across the team there should be no bottlenecks of people who
are the only ones who know about that subject matter so that's a really important thing to
call out as well i do like to acknowledge that sometimes it's impossible to push things to the
team and here it's really important as a leaders to make sure that you're providing context so to the team and also
to leadership so you know to the team maybe we have to back into you know this business priority
and de-prioritize some tech debt that we've been really really wanting to do for a long time um because we have a financial contract
so we just have to back into so giving the team that context as a leader is really really important
and on the flip side like i said you're also that one providing context to leaders so here's why it's important that my
development team is working on this you know here's why it matters to you leader you know it's going to improve
performance and here's why you care about that so i think it's really important as leaders that we're just like over
communicating you know you have access to a lot more information than a lot of people on the team and
then also upper level leadership have and so connecting the dots and sharing that information is super super vital
another thing i like to call it is that great leaders are really really good simplifiers so similar to what i said
before you know you have access to a lot of information and oftentimes you are required to take a ton of
information and scale it down to like a note card sized update to save time for
you know your team just to get those beats bits of relevant information or for leadership too so i have a weekly team huddle um
where i like to bring the three teams that um are on my in my organization together just to make sure that i am
using it as a place to share information um and so our agenda that we walk
through is you know tio so we use this week i learned so any new technology or something you know
stupid that i feel like i did that i learned the team just opens up and and shares those types of things
um and then organizational updates or context you know clarifying team vision if i'm finding people are asking the
same questions and one-on-ones over and over again i'm gonna bring that up just so that everyone you know can hear my response
and so that everyone's on the same page for those and then i also like to have guest speakers um so having folks from across
the organization come in and talk about you know here is our application here's how it fits in and here's
you know why it matters to you and as you know this development team so i think this is especially important
at large organizations as a way to you know build a network and also figure out where we sit in this
organization so if i've learned anything you know context is huge you know in feedback people want to know
the why they want to know why we're working on this and feel really great about the products that they're building
number three is to share credit take blame developers can oftentimes get lost
especially at large organizations when they are working on these big initiatives you know but a smaller piece of it
um so i think it's important that we're associating names with accomplishments and also acknowledging and this is
really important that not all recognition looks the same so you know when onboarding make sure
that you're getting to know that person and what they prefer for recognition so some people love
being recognized at an all team meeting in front of 100 people and some would hate that so make sure
that you're understanding how they prefer to be recognized for good work on the team
now the take blame piece as a leader um you know we work in technology things go wrong we have to react to
production issues and take accountability when things do go wrong um and so this is where it's really
important important that you're extremely loyal when you're recovering from an ugly failure as a
team you're not pointing fingers you're not bringing up names here um you know it's your team you're accountable and
responsible for the results of of the product so i'm always asking what is your role
then during a production issue and i think this changes for every engineering manager um but for myself i find that you know
i'm shielding the team as their troubleshooting issues oftentimes they can get bombarded with questions and
updates and how are things going shield the team make sure they have the space to work through the issue
hopefully you're participating in troubleshooting efforts just by asking you know how can you help you know what do you need right now
um you're getting out of the way if anything just to make sure again you're shielding them in that way
um you're leading the team through the rca and implementing tools to prevent future occurrences
and then you're speaking on behalf of the team after major incidents too so you're the one to represent it you
know to talk through here's what we learned whatever kind of ceremony your organization has hopefully you're
representing unless someone on the team really wants to do that but again you are the one accountable for for the quality
number four is to never devalue people in the process of delivering a solution and i
think this one is my favorite all right so what i've come to learn is that when it comes to
humans abstraction is bad um you know we're not an assembly lines and even those who are in assembly lines
you know what someone can produce and what someone is worth at work is a lot more complex than we can safely
put numbers around and i truly believe that value is described and should be described in
so many different ways um i love this quote you know i think it's so true we look at people and their performance and
you know what they are incentivized by um so tell me how you measure me and i will then tell you how i behave
um so looking at you know what do you incentivize your team by like what are you talking about is it the number of commits is it your
test coverage is that the stories completed like these things you can easily put numbers around um
these are actually the things that i like to avoid talking about when i talk about you know success and high performers
high performing engineers and you know when we look at our annual reviews um instead i like to talk about
mentorship you know how did you help another person level up this year and improve their skill sets um code
quality like let's look at code quality as a whole and not necessarily test coverage as a
percentage um and then what is your ability to understand and translate business
problems so some of these more soft skills so things that are a lot harder to put numbers around
um and harder to incentivize i think are a lot more important
now switching gears here a little bit you know there's so many different studies about diversity and how impactful and
beneficial it is to organizations um you know there's so many unique ways that employees think and learn and
relate to others you know approach their work personally and also just see the world and so we have to make sure that we're
celebrating and reaping the benefits of you know the unique characteristics of each individual
um if you're a numbers person here are some stats um so you know over half of the population
consider workplace diversity an important factor when considering where to work um and more than 50 of current employees
want their own workplaces to do more to increase diversity and then when we just look at like success rates and performance and
financials organizations with above average gender diversity and levels of engagement
outperform companies um by 46 to 58 um and so as leaders we have to make
sure that you know our employees are able to be their authentic selves every day at work without question
you know i've learned that people are going to bring their whole human self to work every day even if they try not to and it
can be really draining to try to spend that energy you know trying to hide these essential elements of who you are
you know instead i want you to spend your energy building awesome technology and so this is where inclusion comes in
you know you have to be a leader that fosters a really really inclusive environment um and also an environment in which
someone can approach you and talk to you if they feel like a certain situation wasn't meeting those
expectations of an inclusive environment as well just a quick twit that i've learned the
hard way you know make sure you're finding out what religious or cultural holidays and days are significant to the team members
um if possible i know it's not always feasible you know offering them that time off or at a minimum just be aware
of them so that you know when they do take that time off they're not on call you know you're not paying them for questions etc you're
respecting that time off if they have to take vacation for it now i like to talk about how this lack
of diversity on our engineering teams has failed us in different ways you know it's failed us in the products
that we're delivering as well so from facial recognition software to crash tests
you know this diversity even becomes deadly to our users and i have a hypothesis for why this
occurs you know i think building software to solve a new problem is all about creativity um and i love
this definition of creativity it's about making unexpected connections between things
that we already know and so if our teams are made up of the exact same type of person
with similar experiences and backgrounds you know we wouldn't be able to come up with creative solutions
and so therefore the quality of our software is affected directly by the degree of diversity on an engineering
team just because the range of possible solutions to an engineering problem are going to be significantly smaller on
a non-diverse team and so that's why it's super important you know for many reasons to have a diverse
and inclusive engineering team now i think there's some attributes where diversity actually doesn't make
sense and in hiring i'm making sure that we don't have diversity when hiring for these things
um so the first thing is values you know if someone's values don't align to the organization that they work for
they're going to be spending a lot of energy fighting it and trying to convince themselves they're in the right roles or at the right organizations
you know so for example if you're you know big advertiser of cigarettes to children like you're just gonna have a really hard
time coming to work every day and feeling great about the products that you're building assuming that aligns with your values
um the second one is work ethic so you know only hiring motivated driven and curious people
obviously you have your day off but i need that to be your normal day it's just really strong work ethic then
there's attitude you know only hiring people again with the majority of the time having a really positive attitude being
open to things being open to change and you know approachable to what from other engineers
and then lastly past failures you know you have to be willing to talk about learn from and also apply those
learnings about past failures to your current role so in interviewing you know making sure we're asking people to talk through
their past failures what they learned from and how they applied you know their learnings to their current situations or past
projects number five is being vulnerable and
authentic as a leader um the first thing i like to talk there is make sure that as a leader you're also articulating your own stories of
struggle so you know whether you fail that something and you want to share that so you make sure that other others also feel comfortable
to share those types of learnings um be relatable so that others feel comfortable to come
forward that's just going to make our cultures so much better
and then along the lines of being authentic um i was shocked to learn that my dad had a picture of mr ed as his
linkedin profile i was like how do people take you seriously um you know he's a consultant
so he's working with recruiters and you know trying to find you know roles every now and then um and he said you know i don't want to
work for a company that doesn't have a little humor and wasn't okay with my weird personality and this has really actually stuck with
me um you know when he is one of those like retention stats and metrics you have to care about you know he has
30 plus years of software experience um and there's a lot of people in the industry like him
who you know feel the same way like i want to be in an organization which i can be my authentic self
so as a leader i think it's important that not only you're doing that yourself but you're also promoting that type of environment
number six is to prioritize and focus and this is definitely a little bit more of a drier tip so i apologize but i
think it is super super super important um because now that you're a manager you know you're going to have to welcome
interruptions um you're going from that make your calendar it was probably a lot more free than it
looks now and now you have a manager calendar that's just absolutely packed with meetings and conversations all that all day
um and so looking at some tips for what helps especially new managers adapt to this
let's take a look at those experts of success so when asked one word to define their
success both bill gates and warren buffett said the ability to focus
and i completely agree you know as a manager you're bombarded with distracting ideas and information
opinions and fires coming up um you start your week with a plan and that a
lot of you know that rarely happens that you're following through with those same commitments that you made because more important things are coming
up and you have to be able to distinguish what is important um so you know as a leader you're able to say
you know what really matters at this given moment what should i direct my attention to my energy to
um you know whether it's the people on your team that need help um maybe it's you know helping the team troubleshoot a
production issue maybe it's a business partner that you need to work on a relationship with or have a hard conversation with
um i think this is a skill that a lot of leaders are lacking because they are feeling really overwhelmed with that new calendar that
they're seeing and speaking of being all overwhelmed um
i'd like to say you know has ever has anyone ever said this to your boss or had someone say this to you um i think a better way to translate
this and to speak to solving this problem is actually looking at what does that mean you know i think i'm trying to
think or do about too many priorities at the same time or i don't have the proper resources or support so getting into and digging into
you know why are you feeling overwhelmed or why is someone on your team feeling overwhelmed and what can you help them do to get
through that is really important also just acknowledging you know when you say
yes to something you are saying no to something else we only have a certain amount of time in the day in a week
um and so making sure like i said before you're focusing on the most important things um not being distracted
by some of those you know cool exciting initiatives that you could work on but maybe they don't really align to your overall goals
of a leader of your specific team now some more tactical tips um stop
multitasking on the important things um it does cause a 10 drop in iq and
leads to as much as 40 drop in productivity um you know so studies show that the human
brain actually can't handle more than one task at a time even if you think you're multitasking and getting a lot done um
number one your you know your iq is a lot lower while you're doing those tests so are you really doing high quality
work um but no you're not even multitasking your brain is just switching rapidly between those tasks and that's probably
why these stats are the way they are now some email tips
um i like to prioritize emails you know with keywords indicating urgency um possibilities to unblock team members
you know definitely messages that are addressed only to you you can't assume that someone else is going to get to that
so making sure you're prioritizing or delegating those types of emails also killing long email chains when
possible um there's nothing worse you know than coming into into work and having a huge email chain
you have to read through the context and maybe answer a simple question so hop on a phone call or you know send
that person a message to understand that context before making someone else then read through the chain if you're responding
calendar calendars do exist to organize and communicate what i like to do is scan my calendar
and on friday and then first thing every morning and look at you know are there any meetings that i should be skipping
um canceling and giving the people time back or sending a proxy are there any meetings that i'm invited
to that i could be considered optional um also looking to make sure there there aren't several meetings in a day that
drain your energy um and ensuring that there are some that actually energize you that you can look forward to participating in
um and this one often you know goes um people talk about it but they don't do it make sure you're blocking time for
unplanned work you know travel time lunch bathroom breaks like whatever that is to me you need to feel energized and
productive throughout the day make sure you're respecting your time in that way let's jump into meetings make sure
you're making and sharing an agenda if you're the owner of that meeting identifying the purpose you know both in
the invite and verbally when starting the meeting um do attendees need to complete any preparation you know there's nothing
worse than getting an inmate for a meeting and having no idea what will be discussed or decided at that meeting it's really unproductive
um also make sure you aren't just sharing updates because we can use technology for that
um so email or slack like if it's a one-way update just send an email just use slack don't
hold the meeting for that also i think it's important that you're considering the timing of meetings
especially when developers are involved so i like to say that you know as a developer you're working in like
four-hour chunks it's really hard to pull everything down and dig into a problem in you know less
than a couple hours or even an hour um so when you're scheduling meetings look at who's coming
and try to respect that time as much as possible so for example i try to do my one-on-ones maybe at the
start of the day or the end of the day um and really try to avoid when possible to schedule them in the middle of the day
some more on meetings you know certain people are dominating the conversation um as a great facilitator
you're asking others for ideas you're pointing out you know hey you've been a little quiet um what is your insight on this um
you're also ensuring that the meeting stays on topic there's nothing worse again than showing up to meeting with expectations
of what you're going to talk about and then it's a completely different conversation that just throws you off um you're
summarizing the results of the discussion and to confirm everyone is on the same page and also capturing action items and next
steps so people feel like something is going to be done with you know this important conversation that took up their time
my seventh and last tip is to always invest in your communication
talk about one-on-ones you know one-on-ones are hard but they are the most important aspect
of our roles and so we do have to prioritize them because we have them for a lot of different reasons
we have to take a pulse on the person and the team to uncover potential issues we use them to foster
trust and gain alignment to give feedback to discuss career direction and to provide
context as i talked about before some tips i've learned the hard way um number one is to just stop talking
you know as the leader it's all about the other person and what they want to talk about um so it's not up to you to do all the
talking instead you're asking really great questions and listening and letting that person talk about what's on their mind
um speaking of listening you have to be a really really great leader um i'm sorry great listener to be a
great leader so you're focusing your attention on the other person without distraction
um you're asking follow-up questions you're paraphrasing you're clarifying um you're also observing the person's
energy and again emotional intelligence that's where this is huge um so you're looking at their
mood you know high or low energy something else going on that you should be talking about body language you know what isn't being
said for one-on-ones just kind of core tenants for myself
i make sure they're regularly scheduled for my team members minimum every other week for 30 minutes they're
rarely missed and again like i said they're focused on the other team member so some questions that i like to use to
get the conversation going if needed are you know what is on your mind i love this one because it avoids that awkward
silence um it's a question that says let's talk about you know what matters most to you at this given moment
and i've actually never had anyone you know say nothing which i was super surprised when i introduced this
question to my one-on-one format um and so i really love it you know what's on your mind this week what should we be talking about
and then there's you know say more so i think context and details really matter even if you think you understand what
they're talking about just ask them to say more to clarify and to truly understand i always end our
conversations with you know how can i help this week what do you need um i love this one because you're forcing them to make a clear and direct
request and you're not assuming that you know what's best for them or what they need you know already we have you know our
time is spent doing a lot of things and so i don't want to spend my day doing things that i think people want me to do
um but instead just asking them and i love this one you know what is the most challenging thing you're working on
right now um so helping them tie the specific work that they're doing to some of their
technical and career goals this is a great one to talk through those types of things
so to recap you know leaders don't provide the answers instead they ask a lot of really great questions
um and so on my website you can find a list of all of these you can also just do a

one-on-ones to continue moving the conversation forward really productively
so i just like to wrap up by saying you know people are our most important assets and so we have to be
